instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.SMC_BC_OK: What is SMC_BC_OK? This is a typo of SMC_BC_ACOK When you see SMC_BC_OK, assume they meant to type SMC_BC_ACOK.
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light on charger with battery plugged in
threads.message: i have an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that wont get a green light while the battery is plugged in, if you unplug the battery and plug in the charger you get a green light computer can boot ect, then if you plug the battery in while the charger is plugged in it will charge normally greenlight stays, but when the batterys plugged in and the charger is plugged in after, it will not give a green light

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light on charger with battery plugged in
threads.message: 3V42 still present with battery connected? Do an SMC reset on the keyboard with battery plugged in, does the green light appear after that?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light on charger with battery plugged in
threads.message: pp3v42 present with just the battery connected, smc reset did nothing

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light on charger with battery plugged in
threads.message: also i can rule out the battery because i have tested with a known good one

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light on charger with battery plugged in
threads.message: computer recognizes and runs off the battery, just no green light from the charger, like i said if i have the charger plugged in and its running i can plug the battery in and itll charge then but after the charger is unplugged and then replugged in it will no longer charge or give a light

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light on charger with battery plugged in
threads.message: This happens to me when the transistor creating <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> gets stuck and sends 16v to <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>. the system will still work but it disables the charger when battery is plugged in so 16v doesn't go to the battery and smoke it.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light on charger with battery plugged in
threads.message: so replacing <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR> should do the trick? <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is at 12.55v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light on charger with battery plugged in
threads.message:
Nvm, that isn't it then. 

What happened to this machine originally to cause this? Water, bad DIY repair attempt, drop?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light on charger with battery plugged in
threads.message: water, they took it somewhere else first, it looks like they cleaned the board somehow but the water detection circles are white besides by the lcd connector and i can see a little left over corrosion under the board by the backlight data line caps, this machine had no backlight which i repaired, the traces were fried on the lcd data lines

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light on charger with battery plugged in
threads.message: I also checked current sensing before and after the isl all the resistors are good

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light on charger with battery plugged in
threads.message: every once in a while the charger will not give a green light even when the battery is out, it will like flash green then go off then after a couple seconds itll come green then flash off again then it will randomly work fine, possibly dying isl?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light on charger with battery plugged in
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light on charger with battery plugged in
threads.message: okay i will try a reflow when i get home, hopefully that will do it for me

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light on charger with battery plugged in
threads.message: reflow didnt work, any other ideas?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light on charger with battery plugged in
threads.message: if i shorted pp3v42 to the <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_OK</SIGNAL> line it should force the charger to work right?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light on charger with battery plugged in
threads.message:
Really not recommended to do that, its there for a reason. Shorting <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_OK</SIGNAL> to pp3v42 might damage the SMC and will also possibly start the SMC before the power is actually stable which can cause weird issues.

Is the charger a known good charger? Might be pulling too much because it tries to charge the battery and boot the system, but unlikely the issue. Also check out the <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> area, if all passive components measure alright you can try to replace it. Otherwise might be SMC related, not sure.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light on charger with battery plugged in
threads.message: No, you figure out why ACOK is not coming high. There is not much on this line that could be an issue.
